## **Description**
The **Format Number **operator allows to modify the format of a numeric value provided in input, according to the configured settings.

## **Input**
**Input**

**Data type**

**Description**

**in0**

Number

The numeric value for which you want to modify the format.

## **Output**
**Output**

**Data Type**

**Description**

**out0**

Number

The result of the reformatting operation based on the configured settings.

## **Settings**
**![](data:image/png;base64,)**

- In the **Input Format **section:

From the **Format **drop-down menu, select the format of the input value. The available options are:

**Default**: The operator interprets the numeric input value based on the locale defined at runtime.

- **System**: The operator interprets the numeric input value as a system number, without thousands separator and using "." as a decimal separator.

- **Custom**: The operator interprets the numeric input value based on the custom locale defined by the user in the configuration settings.

- If you selected the "Custom" format, the **Locale **field is enabled. From the drop-down menu, select the locale that the operator will use to interpret the numeric input value.

- In the **Output Format **section:

From the **Format **drop-down menu, select the format to use for the output value. The available options are:

**Default**: The operator outputs a numeric value based on the locale defined at runtime.

- **System**: The operator outputs a numeric value as a system number, without thousands separator and using "." as a decimal separator.

- **Custom**: The operator outputs a numeric value based on the custom locale defined by the user in the configuration settings.

- Configure the required parameters, based on the selected output format:

**Format**

**Field**

**Field Type**

**Field Description**

**Default**

**Decimals**

Integer

Enter the number of decimal digits of the output number.

> Note

If set to ***0***, the operator returns an integer number.

If set to ***-1***, the operator will maintain the same number of decimal digits in the input number.

**Use 1000**

**separator**

Checkbox

Select this option to enable or disable usage of the thousands separator in the output number.

> Note

The separator character depends on the selected locale.

**System**

**Decimals**

Integer

Enter the number of decimal digits of the output number.

> Note

If set to ***0***, the operator returns an integer number.

If set to ***-1***, the operator will maintain the same number of decimal digits in the input number.

**Custom**

**Custom Locale**

Drop-down menu

Select the locale that the operator will use for the output number from the drop-down menu.

**Pattern**

Text

Define the structure of the output number. The allowed characters are listed in the following table:

**Character**

**Description**

**0**

Digit

**#**

Digit; zero is not displayed

**.**

Decimal separator

**-**

Minus sign

**,**

Thousands separator

**E**

Separator between mantissa and exponent in scientific notation

**;**

Separator between positive and negative number patterns

**%**

Multiplies by 100 and displays the number as a percentage

**'**

Used to insert special characters

- Click **Apply **to confirm.

## **Special cases**
In special cases, the operator behaves as follows:

**Case**

**Behavior**

NULL input (no input)

The operator returns an empty string.

NULL input value

The operator returns an empty string.

NON NUMERIC input value

The operator returns an empty string.
